Little Hell Engine

Little Hell Engine (or just "little hell") is a project that aims to re-imagine the idTech 1 for the modern day.

Motivation

Goals

Starting with a true to the original source port of DOOM (Chocolate DOOM) as its foundation, the little hell engine aims to:

  • Foundationally shift from being a source port to being a standalone game engine
  • Renovate the idTech1 codebase and bring it into the 21st century using modern C best practices, with a cozy, high-level API
  • Maintain the 'soul' of idTech1, without the baggage of legacy code and support for hardware that is older than I am.
  • Facilitate the creation of new boomer shooters and other retro-style games built on the same roots of DOOM.

Features (Planned)

Scripting support with Lua

Adding scripting language support enables Developers to write code for their games in a higher-level language instead of C. Lua is the natural choice, as it is very common in game development and is designed to be embedded into/interoperate with C code.

Lua support would be analogous to ZScript, ACS, FraggleScript, etc, found in DOOM source ports, but with a few extra advantages:

  • Developers won't need to learn a domain-specific language. Lua is very popular as a scripting engine in game development, and Lua programming is a portable skill.
  • Lua is a mature language with its own ecosystem, package manager, etc.

Support for Zig

Zig is a general-purpose programming language that sports interoperability with C as a major feature. Developers should be able to choose Zig as their programming language of choice to create games with Little Hell.

DOOM limit removal

The DOOM engine originally had a number of static limits placed upon it that we're not going to want.

Patches from Crispy Doom

Crispy Doom (a fork of Chocolate Doom, the basis of our engine) has a number of really great things that most anyone would want in an engine. These include:

  • Widescreen support
  • High-resolution rendering
  • Uncapped frame rate
  • Mouse free look
  • Jumping

These Crispy Doom features should be implemented in Little Hell, either by patching our code or re-implementing some of them ourselves.

Examples

Soon!

The little hell engine uses the game code for DOOM 1 as its test bed. Development of the engine is done in tandem with the development of our own version of DOOM I (v1.9 Registered Version) running on the little hell engine. When we begin to add new functionality to the engine (as opposed to just rewriting large quantities of it), attention will switch to creating a demo game designed to showcase and utilize all of the engine functionality.

Building

git clone https://github.com/ranguli/mindoom
cd doom
nix-shell shell.nix
meson build
ninja -C build
